comments.commentBody:
Article says "One number that he had provided when he last entered the United States, in February, was stored in a Customs and Border Protection database."
For the individual liberties people that believe that "you cannot store any personal information without the person's consent," this case would not have been solved if the number had not been stored in a database.

Read comment 393 by AC .

Absolutely correct and absolutely brilliant!!

The police took pains to inform the media the details of why the bomb attempt failed even telling what was done incorrectly. They provided all the information terrorists need to make sure the next bomb is built right and goes off as planned. When will the police learn?
Of course he did not act alone.

Per #118--no need to worry--the Patriot Act is working just fine.  After all, a team of government investigators, working under Patriot Act authority, were able to catch former Governor Spitzer allegedly engaging in appropriate activity and crossing state lines while at it.

Excellent observation by Baker from Chicago. It is valuable to unserscore his point-why is it that two countries born at the same time have taken such different paths? Pakistan's inability to understand responsible behavior and to suffer from an enlightenment of broad horizons it appears is initially discussed in her family rooms with by adults and parents; in schools by teachers anthen endorsed all the way up by the rulingglite i.the military machinery which has ruled the country and constantaly harps a jingoistic and parochial attitude towards anything foriegn, be it India, Afghanistan or the rest of thworld with a differing viewpoint.
India, on the other hand it appears at the grass roots celebrates education; achievement and ambition in a far superior measure than its westward neighbor. the results are there to see. Both countries struggle with poverty in immense measure, but one occupies a nuisance and blackmailing value today in the world and the other encourages civilizational development.
The only thing that needs to be supported financially in Pakistan today with US taxpayer money is EDUCATION and schooling; not the military, if that failed country and her people have to be brought back into a developmental mode, as undoutedly there are enough good folks I suspect even now in Pakistan. (but, just be careful you don't try go finding where they are- remember Danny Pearl!)

All the evidence about the culprit makes sense only if he was actually recruited some years ago by our military as a spy--a double agent. He was able to get in deep into the enemy's camps, perform a foiled attack for us, retain his cover by getting noticed and caught, and then provide to our agencies the information that they need. He was actually a very dedicated patriotic American, who is guaranteed a polite mock trial, a short term stay in prison with very many luxuries that will go unnoticed by the mass media, and shortly thereafter unpublicized release somewhere--or documents will be switched so that some actual prisoner of similar appearance will cooperate with authorities, assume his name, and be moved into a different prison where the other prisoners would not be able to identify him as a substitute. . . . And even if it did not happen this time--this is a good scheme for Homeland Security and our armed forces to consider and adopt.
This looks like a diversion tactic to me. Testing the responses of the authorities. I hope I am wrong.

Reading all these comments only tells me one thing Americans haven't learned since 9/11. There can never be 100% security in any country or by any administration. If we want that than we have to change the fundamental basis of the freedoms we enjoy--it is a tough balancing act. We do need comprehensive immigration reform, however, and it is beyond me how the airlines still sell walk-up one way tickets paid for with cash.

For those of you city slickers who think the US didn't already outlaw potassium nitrate in powder form which was used in the OK City bombing, that is not an option for anyone, even irate farmers. Maybe he financed his operation growing a cash crop. The Taliban finances most of their operations by farming.

Leaving aside whether American military involvement in Iraq, Afghanistan, and now Pakistan is justified or not on national security grounds, am I the only person to whom it has occurred that there are an awful lot of people in those countries who have been brutalized by American troops and interrogators or who have lost innocent loved ones -- particularly children -- to errant American weaponry?

My guess is that there are a lot of people out there, with legitimate grievances or not, who would like to blow our country off the map. Sometimes I wish I had the money or the marketable skills to move to another, safer country -- if there is one -- before America's wars come home to "the homeland" (which we used to call "our country" when I was a kid).
So why doesn't the congress listen to Bloomberg and close the loophole?

It is hilarious that US Immigration agents DO NOT CHECK PASSPORTS on departure. Even in a country like India ALL departing passengers are checked for - valid documentation for entry to visiting country, the names are run through a database which has a list of names that have legal cases (those that require that you not leave India) pending in the courts against them. The list also includes people who have tax evasion cases against them. Maybe the US ought to learn a few things from us. We have had a very long history at being victims of terrorism and have lost more people to terrorist acts than the US.

Consistently for the last 10 plus years terrorists or would-be terrorists are not entering the US by the borders with Canada or with Mexico. We do need Mexican cheap labor to sustain our economy, and compete against China and heavily subsidized Europe. So let`s stop linking security (as in terrorism) with immigration.
Now let`s focus on who are we letting in with legal papers, and worse, US citizens with links to terrorist groups. The terrorists groups are not going to cross the desert of Arizona under a 120 degree sun, they are recruiting people who are legally inside the US !!
If we don`t understand that, then everything else is in trouble!

Brandon, I hope you don't teach math... One of the reasons kids learn so little in this country is because of how ignorant so many teachers are.

That said, I agree with the point that bailing out wall street with middle class taxes is just nuts. Not what's going on in greece, where public sector employees have just been consuming more than there is there for them (much like most of the US northeast).

But the middle class in the US is getting hosed. Socialism for wall street from main street is nuts. You don't need a bad understanding of statistics to believe that.

I have no sympathy for these people. People can blame the shadowy banking cabal if they want to but the Greeks are acting like spoiled children. They had their fun on borrowed money and now the bill has came due. They are not the only ones this is happening to it is global occurrence. It is happening to us and no one is in the street hurling Molotov cocktails at bank building and killing innocent employees.

Spoiled children need discipline and Greece needs to be kicked out the Euro with no bailouts. The Germans and French can bailout their affected banks if they chose to do so.

According to an employee of the bank:

"The management of the bank strictly bared the employees from leaving today, even though they had persistently asked so themselves from very early this morning – while they also forced the employees to lock up the doors and repeatedly confirmed that the building remained locked up throughout the day, over the phone. They even blocked off their internet access so as to prevent the employees from communicating with the outside world." http://athens.indymedia.org...

It also appears that fire safety regulations were completely flouted at this particular building. Tragic regardless.

To those who assail "socialism" and "Obama policies" for creating situations like this, I ask you, why is it not happening here in Australia? Here we have excellent social services and socialised health care (despite what whingeing Aussies say about it) and yet, the economy is still strong. There are many reasons for this and it may yet still blow up one day, but if it does so, it will be due to over-consumption, not government structure. I grow so tired of listening to brainwashed red-scare generation Americans blame socialistic policies for these types of outcomes. Get over it, the problem is rooted entirely in GREED on the part of those at all levels of society and foolish spending on behalf of average civilians. Blame government all you want, but it has to do more with mismanagement than whether or not they are socialist or capitalist (the latter word being one so many people confuse with "democracy", you can be socialist and democratic at the same time). The corruption of these governments by corporate interests (and in some countries, mafias) combined with reckless spending by the people who want lifestyles they can't afford caused this mess. And to John S, #4, don't worry about this kind of uprising in the US, you're far too lazy for that. Otherwise it would've happened 8 years ago at the first signs that Bush was clearly hell-bent on bringing the whole place down.

The last I checked, Greece is a democracy.  Yet, the Greeks are acting as if their government is owned by Mafia. Shouldn't people take the ultimate responsibility for their "government of the people"?  It's them who put their politicians in power, after all.

turn off the phones, use minimal electric, walk when you can, grow a garden, buy only the staples. learn to sew. get real. its coming to the usa too.   too long living a dream. too many freebies for anyone wanting to hustle the system. we will get that 40 years in the wilderness.

I don't see the people of Iceland and Ireland burning, looting, and murdering despite the drastic cuts that they were forced to make.  The Greeks might have been the cradle of civilization, but now they are spoiled children.

Shahzad was on no terrorist watch list so, in his case, the point is moot. He was totally below the radar.

However, terrorists sneaking into the country unarmed and then purchasing arms is a legitimate worry. The NY Times ran a story on how easily Shahzad purchaseed his machine-pistol. Also, if you can buy guns you can also buy gun powder and ammunition and use the gun powder and ammunition to make a truly potent, deadly explosive.

When the founders wrote the Constitution, the Second Amendment was added so the citizens could, as a last resort, run out a tyrant if one had taken over the democracy. The goal was to preserve the democratic government.

The goal of a terrorist is to destroy our government. Therefore, contrary to what Senator Graham argues, the Founding Fathers would have agreed with restricting of the opportunity of terrorists to buy arms.

I am a strong gun-ownership rights person. I started shooting when I was ten and still target shoot. I enjoy the challenge of mastering the man-machine interaction.

However, I'm also a strong commonsense person and believe in avoiding extremes. Mentally ill people should not have access to firearms, people with a record of violence should not have access to firearms and people suspected enough of being a terrorist that they end up on the terrorist watch list, should not have access to firearms.

Oh, and Senator Graham's, "... we need to slow down and think about this," comment. The first time I ever saw that rhetorical technique was in an English-language version of Pravda, the old Soviet state newspaper. It was one of their common rhetorical devices used to show that the "state" was the wise leader because it didn't rush into things - such as change. Making it more difficult for suspected terrorists to obtain guns, ammunition and gun powder is common sense legislation we do need to rush into.

I like your idea. I would love to be able to choose what my taxes go for--every dollar. Perhaps we can start with something that our money is actually going towards right now, like our international wars or social security or government bailouts. As a deserving person (because I was born in the United States) I am entitled to such freedom of choice, que no?

But back to health care and being worthy. If we stop giving out medical care to one group of people, like pregnant women who are citizens of another country, perhaps we'll get a huge tax refund. Maybe I'll use that money to go to Mexico. Women without visas or U.S. passports should not get health care because they do not deserve it. Does that mean that women who are citizens who currently do not have health care are being denied something they deserve? Are there some U.S. legal citizens that deserve health care more than others? Are there some people that deserve health care more than others? Seems to me like the people most immediately in need are the ones who should get healthcare, regardless of whether not we judge them as morally deserving. If a person is bleeding uncontrollably do they not derserve medical attention? I guess it depends on where they were born.
36%? You're joking, right?
When did loansharking become legal? I guess I missed that memo. No thank you.
